[[Duke University]] |awards = Fellow of the [[American Academy of Arts and Sciences]] }} '''James W. Vaupel''' (born May 2, 1945), is an American scientist in the fields of [[aging research]], [[biodemography]], and formal [[demography]]. He has been instrumental in developing and advancing the idea of the plasticity of [[longevity]], and pioneered research on the heterogeneity of mortality risks and on the deceleration of [[death rates]] at the highest ages.{{cite journal |doi=10.1126/science.1069675 |title=DEMOGRAPHY: Enhanced: Broken Limits to Life Expectancy |year=2002 |last1=Oeppen |first1=J. |journal=Science |volume=296 |issue=5570 |pages=1029–31 |pmid=12004104 |last2=Vaupel |first2=JW}}{{psc|date=October 2011}}{{cite journal |doi=10.1126/science.280.5365.855 |title=Biodemographic Trajectories of Longevity |year=1998 |last1=Vaupel |first1=J. A. |last5=Harvald |first5=Bent |last6=Vaupel |first6=James W. |journal=Human Genetics |volume=97 |issue=3 |pmid=8786073}}{{psc|date=October 2011}} ==Current positions== Vaupel is the founding director of the [[Max Planck Institute for Demographic Research]] in [[Rostock]], Germany (since 1996). He is also a research professor at [[Duke University]] and the director of its Population, Policy, Aging and Research Center. Vaupel is a member of the [[German Academy of Sciences Leopoldina]], a regular scientific member of the [[U.S. National Academy of Sciences]] and fellow of the [[American Academy of Arts and Sciences]].{{cite web | url = http://user.demogr.mpg.de/jwv | title = Prof. Dr. James W. Vaupel}}{{self-published inline|date=October 2011}} He has been involved in many endeavors and published over 20 books.{{cite web | url = http://user.demogr.mpg.de/jwv/cgi-bin/publications.plx | title = Publications by year}}{{self-published inline|date=October 2011}}{{cite web | url = http://edoc.mpg.de/display.epl | title = Quick Search "Vaupel" | work = Max Planck Society - eDoc Server}}{{self-published inline|date=October 2011}} ==Contributions== Convinced that formal demography is the source of the discipline’s strength, Vaupel has contributed to the methodological foundations of demography. In 2001 he was awarded by the Population Association of America the Irene B. Taeuber Award for his lifetime research achievements.{{cite web | title = Irene B.Taeuber Awardees | url = http://www.popassoc.org/i4a/pages/index.cfm?pageid=3306 | publisher = Population Association of America}} In 2008 he received the Mindel C. Sheps Award for his work in mathematical demography.{{cite web | title = Mindel C. Sheps Awardees | url = http://www.popassoc.org/i4a/pages/index.cfm?pageid=3307 | publisher = Population Association of America}} Vaupel has been a leading proponent of the idea of the plasticity of longevity.{{Cite document| title = The Plasticity of Longevity: Interview with James Vaupel | url = http://www.sagecrossroads.net/files/transcript21.pdf | publisher = SAGE Crossroads | date = 14 December 2004 | format = PDF| postscript = {{inconsistent citations}} }} Many people believe there is a looming limit to human [[life expectancy]]. Vaupel’s research shows that life expectancy is likely to increase well beyond the purported limit of 85 years.{{cite news | title = Hell No, We Won't Go! Surprising demographic trends raise a tough question: Will the elderly live so long that society can't cope? | newspaper = CNN Money | url = http://money.cnn.com/magazines/fortune/fortune_archive/1999/07/19/263116/index.htm | date = 19 July 1999 | first = David | last = Stipp}} Furthermore, Vaupel and others (such as Bernard Jeune of [[Denmark]]) advanced a new proposition: that the human [[life expectancy|life span]] is not fixed, but is a function of [[life expectancy]] and [[population size]]. He and [[S. Jay Olshansky]] have had a disagreement about what this means in terms of future projections of the human life span.{{cite magazine | title = Staying Alive | magazine = Discover | section = Health & Medicine / Aging | url = http://discovermagazine.com/2003/nov/cover | first = Karen | last = Wright | date = November 2003}} Vaupel’s work also focuses on the nascent field of evolutionary demography. His research activities here strive to understand age-specific mortality in terms of the evolutionary processes that shape it.{{cite journal |jstor=3401355 |pages=258–269 |last1=Vaupel |first1=J. W. |title=Post-Darwinian Longevity |volume=29 |journal=Population and Development Review |year=2003}}{{psc|date=October 2011}} Because in his studies, particular attention is paid to mortality improvements at the end of the lifespan, Vaupel has been instrumental in the emerging field of research into [[supercentenarians]] as a population subset.{{cite journal | last = Robine | first =J.-M. | first2= J. W. |last2=Vaupel | title = Emergence of supercentenarians in low mortality countries | journal = North American Actuarial Journal | volume = 6 | pages =54–63 |year =2002 | url = http://user.demogr.mpg.de/jwv/pdf/AmActJournal2002.pdf | doi=10.1080/10920277.2002.10596057}} The number of persons aged 110+ in a single European nation is rather small. Vaupel therefore began the push in 2000 by inviting experts from around the world to meet in international workshops{{cite web | url = http://www.demogr.mpg.de/en/calendar/workshops_1.htm | title = Past Workshops}}{{deadlink | date = October 2012}} and to found the International Database on Longevity, which provides information on individuals attaining extreme ages and permits demographic analysis of mortality at the highest ages.{{cite web | url = http://www.supercentenarians.org/ | publisher = International Database on Longevity (www.supercentenarians.org) | title = IDL Project: Introduction}} ==References== {{Reflist|2}} == External links== * [http://www.demogr.mpg.de Max Planck Institute for Demographic Research] * [http://fds.duke.edu/db/aas/PublicPolicy/pparc/primary/vaupel Homepage James Vaupel at Population, Policy and Aging Research Center] * [http://www.mpg.de Max Planck Society] * [http://www.nasonline.org/site/PageServer?pagename=ABOUT_main_page National Academy of Sciences] * [http://www.amacad.org/ American Academy of Arts and Sciences] * [http://www.popassoc.org/ Population Association of America] * [http://www.leopoldina-halle.de/cms/en.html German Academy of Sciences Leopoldina] {{Authority control}} {{Persondata |NAME= Vaupel, James W. |ALTERNATIVE NAMES= |SHORT DESCRIPTION= American demographer |DATE OF BIRTH= 1945-05-02 |PLACE OF BIRTH= [[New York]] |DATE OF DEATH= |PLACE OF DEATH= }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Vaupel, James}} [[Category:1945 births]] [[Category:American demographers]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from New York]] [[Category:Members of the United States National Academy of Sciences]]
